repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**fix(api): update grid cursor in nvim_win_set_cursor()**

Problem:  Cursor position set by nvim_win_set_cursor() is not reflected
          on the screen when followed by a blocking call like getchar().
Solution: Immediately update the cursor position on the grid.

Fix #20793

**fix(ui): ext_cmdline should not move cursor to curwin**

Problem:  The ext_cmdline cursor position on the screen seems to rely on
          an implicit assumption that the event listener implements a
          cmdline window that is made the current window which is
          problematic (e.g. breaks 'incsearch' in the actual current
          window).
Solution: Remove this assumption and allow nvim_win_set_cursor() to move
          the cursor on the screen to a non-current window (previous
          commit).

Fix #20309

comment_data.body: just my immediate reaction, but this part seems to be _very_ different functionality, to the extent it should be a separate API function altogether (perhaps grouped together with other functionality in the _ui_ layer, distinct from window state).

I see. Like I said I didn't have a use case for it yet.
I just went "no opts array" -> nvim_set_cursor() -> add 2 lines for screen relative cursor.
If it isn't wanted perhaps this should just be nvim_win_set_cursor2()?
Or get rid of this screen flag but keep nvim_set_cursor in case we ever want non window related set_cursor API?
Instead, move the cursor back to curwin when leaving the cmdline (and remove duplicate call to `ui_cursor_shape()`).
Is removing duplicate call to `ui_cursor_shape()` really necessary? It doesn't do anything if editor state hasn't changed.
No but why would we keep it? It's called in setmouse() in the line above.
Oh, I thought you were talking about the one in `command_line_check()`. I didn't notice that it's called in `setmouse()`.

comment_regular_data.body:
Full disclosure: I had already succesfully implemented some workarounds for this in #27855 before I came across the previous discussion in #20309. This API serves to be able do without those workarounds; set and draw the cursor position in a window without actually changing `curwin`.

The `screen` key is not really necessary to that end, mostly just added that because it seemed obvious when going from `win_set_cursor` to `set_cursor`.
Using (1,0) indexing for screen position is strange.

> Using (1,0) indexing for screen position is strange.

I thought so too but using different indexing for different options in the same function was even stranger to me. Might be irrelevant if we're not adding `screen`.

> Might be irrelevant if we're not adding screen.

In that case we might as well forego this new API and just resolve this by having `nvim_win_set_cursor()` call `setcursor_mayforce()`. I don't think there is any harm in that?

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(ui): issues controlling cursor position with ext_cmdline
